title: They Called 911 for Help. Police and Prosecutors Used a New Junk Science to Decide They Were Liars.

last_post.content:
They Called 911 for Help. Police and Prosecutors Used a New Junk Science to Decide They Were Liars.
--
People who call 911 don’t know it, but detectives & prosecutors are listening in, ready to assign guilt based on the words they hear.

Some have been wrongfully accused & convicted of murder after someone misinterpreted their call for help, while those who used 911 call analysis against them face little or no consequences.

#Police #911 #FBI #Crime #CriminalJustice

https://www.propublica.org/article/911-call-analysis-fbi-police-courts

title: What explains recent tech layoffs, and why should we be worried? | Stanford News

last_post.content:
' workforce reductions that are happening across the tech industry are a result mostly of “social contagion”' (https://news.stanford.edu/2022/12/05/explains-recent-tech-layoffs-worried/)

I am not sure I agree with such a benign analysis of layoffs.

Have we ruled out "it's a flex to demonstrate who is actually in charge around here"?

I guess "never attribute to malice that which is explained by stupidity" applies here. And based on the article's claims about how badly layoffs work out for companies, stupidity certainly seems involved.

OUT THERE: THE SCIENCE BEHIND SCI-FI FILM AND TV

title: How Twitter misleads us about how many people have left — and what to do about it

last_post.content:
Who do so many people seem unaware of the mass exodus from Twitter?

Social media feeds are engines for distorting our social understanding. But we can push back against the algorithm, with a simple automated out-of-office message on Twitter (how-to included).

This post explains the science of social influence that allows Twitter to maintain an illusion of a full room, how to change that, & why we need industry-independent science for our digital environments.

https://natematias.medium.com/how-twitter-misleads-us-about-how-many-people-have-left-and-what-to-do-about-it-bba484b6fed6

title: #ReceptioGate and the (absolute) state of academia | Charlotte Gauthier | The Critic Magazine

last_post.content: "Unlike scientists, humanities scholars generally need time, rather than large amounts of money, to do their work. A sensible system of research funding that decouples funding from artificial metrics would improve the quality of research and reduce instances of fraud and waste. Proposals for such a system have abounded for years. #ReceptioGate shows, once again, that it’s past time to take another look at them." #ReceptioGate @academicchatter https://thecritic.co.uk/receptiogate-and-the-absolute-state-of-academia/

title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
Taking a closer look at this paper, I really dislike it.

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x

It's clear that newer papers *must* have a lower “disruption” score than older ones under a null model — they even confirm this in the supplemental material with a randomization test. It's an artifact of their definition.

When comparing with the null model they compute only the z-score, getting values at most 4 or so. It's also besides the point — as usual, small meaningless deviations from the null model can be statistically “significant.” Effect size ≠ statistical significance.

Finally, according to their definition, review papers would be “disruptive” because they funnel a bunch of citations. And a paper that does not cite anyone but is universally cited would not be “disruptive”. 🤷

@networkscience
@academicchatter
#networkscience #networks

title: ‘Disruptive’ science has declined — and no one knows why

last_post.content:
I don't necessarily disagree with this take.

But there does seem to me to also be the possibility that most of the low-hanging fruit got picked. If our model of the world is roughly right within the parameters we normally operate, there won't be many radical disruptions.

RT @eric_mccorkle@twitter.com

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-04577-5

Alright... I'm coming out of Twitter retirement to unload on this.

We know damn well why.

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/eric_mccorkle/status/1611158610532528128

title: Petals – Decentralized platform for running 100B+ language models

last_post.content: it annoys me that applications of large language models continue to depend on big-company centralized computing infrastructure, even as text-to-image models become more locally runnable. this looks like an interesting potential (stopgap?) solution: a BitTorrent-style swarm in which each participating machine hosts a small chunk of the full model, enabling distributed inference + fine-tuning https://petals.ml

title: COVID Data Tracker

last_post.content: - XBB.1.5 is surging very rapidly, having increased 10x from 4% of US cases to 41% in just three weeks (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions). It grew out of NY and has become predominant in the northeast US, and experts predict it will spread across the US in the coming weeks. In the past two years, the first week of January was the peak of holiday surges, but this year, it appears we'll see increased transmission and risks throughout January.

title: Shaking the foundations: delusions in sequence models for interaction and control

last_post.content:
If you are learning from a sequence of observations and actions, and using a probabilistic model, you should be treating the agent's actions as #causal interventions. The authors attribute the lack of causal interventions as the reason for #delusions, and also propose a way to do #MetaLearning. #MachineLearning #Causality #ReinforcementLearning

https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.10819

title: Magrit - Cartographie thématique

last_post.content:
Magrit v0.13.0 has been released and is now online on https://magrit.cnrs.fr/ 🗺️
This version notably makes available a new type of contiguous cartograms, those based on the algorithm developed by Gastner, Seguy and More (2018).
The computation is performed solely in the browser thanks to a WebAssembly module (https://www.npmjs.com/package/go-cart-wasm). This is the first use of WebAssembly in Magrit, hoping that it will be satisfactory for the users!

title: Your Face Belongs to Us by Kashmir Hill: 9780593448564 | PenguinRandomHouse.com: Books

last_post.content: My book on facial recognition technology comes out on September 19! Over the last two years, I tracked down the tech's early pioneers, found the people fighting against its worst impulses, and dove into the history of Clearview AI, the start-up that first drew me into the topic with a radical person-finding app that giants in the field, including Google and Facebook, had deemed taboo. It feels real now because there's a release date and a preorder button: https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/691288/your-face-belongs-to-us-by-kashmir-hill/

title: https://thi.ng/geom

last_post.content:
Just added a generic util for splitting polylines with arbitrary predicates to https://thi.ng/geom. For example to separate a polyline into different sets depending on slope, but same function also used for hidden line removal (just using diff. predicate). More #MtHood #Oregon #GIS #DEM visualizations, this time viewed from North to South...

#ThingUmbrella

title: The science of why you have great ideas in the shower

last_post.content:
TIL there's a technical name for why ideas happen in the shower: the "default mode network" is a pattern of brain activity, measurable using fMRI, that happens when we're unfocussed. When the brain goes into idle mode (reduced activity), this part of the brain actually becomes *more* active. What does the default mode network do? Research is ongoing, but part of it definitely seems to be making connections, which is associated with curiosity and creativity.

More here: https://www.nationalgeographic.co.uk/history-and-civilisation/2022/08/the-science-of-why-you-have-great-ideas-in-the-shower

title:
Recap: A Data Catalog for People Who
Hate Data Catalogs

last_post.content:
I'm open sourcing Recap, a dead simple data catalog for engineers! Unlike traditional catalogs, Recap is built to power infrastructure and tools that need metadata.

Check out my blog post for more on why I built Recap and how it's different from traditional catalogs:
https://cnr.sh/essays/recap-for-people-who-hate-data-catalogs

Read the docs:
https://docs.recap.cloud

Or dive straight into the Github repo:
https://github.com/recap-cloud/recap

title: International Space Station Transit Finder

last_post.content:
If you’re at the right place at the right time, with the right equipment, this is possible.

Last night, with guidance from https://transit-finder.com/, I positioned myself along the narrow line where the International #SpaceStation would pass between me and the nearly full moon.

I used a Fujifilm X-T4 shooting 4K video through a Celestron 8” SCT to capture the pass. Then, back at the computer this morning, put together these views with PIPP, Registax, and GIMP.

Quite pleased. My best yet.

title: Episode 161 – A Chat With Matt Mullenweg - Hallway Chats

last_post.content:
Matt Muellenweg re-comits #Tumblr to support #ActivityPub & to join the #Fediverse:

"Tumblr is...not open source yet. But we’ve said it’s going to be & we’ve tried to make the data super open. So the API’s, you can put your Tumblr into WordPress very easily, you can export all your Tumblr content... then longer term, we want to support these new protocols like activity pub on top of… We’re gonna support #RSS so things are easy to get in and out."

https://hallwaychats.com/episodes/episode-161-a-chat-with-matt-mullenweg/

title: Widening Highways Doesn’t Fix Traffic. So Why Do We Keep Doing It?

last_post.content: Widening Highways Doesn't Fix Traffic. So Why Do We Keep Doing It? "If you reduce the price of a good then people will consume more of it. That's essentially what we're doing when we expand freeways." https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/06/us/widen-highways-traffic.html

last_post.content:
Humanity has historically eaten 6,000 plants; now we eat mostly NINE: This is a great (scary) story from Bloomberg on how global diets have converged on a few crops in a few decades – with many alarming implications. Well told (super smart graphics!) #food #climate
